meta.name: Flux.2 Dev
meta.description: Open weights for boundless developer creativity.

cover.alt: An artistic, highly detailed digital painting of a fantasy landscape generated by Flux.2 Dev.

seo.title: Flux.2 Dev - Open Weight 32B Model | z-image.app
seo.description: Access the powerful Flux.2 Dev model online. The open-weight 32B parameter model offering Pro-level quality for non-commercial and developer use. Perfect for testing and LoRA training.
seo.creator: @yeekal

structuredData.name: Flux.2 Dev
structuredData.description: An open-weight, 32-billion parameter AI image model distilled from Flux.2 Pro, offering high-quality generation for developers, researchers, and hobbyists.

hero.title: Flux.2 Dev: Pro Quality, Open Weights
hero.tagline: Experience the raw power of the 32B parameter model. Identical architecture to Pro, optimized for developers, fine-tuners, and those who need granular control.

imageGallery.title: Flux.2 Dev: Raw & Artistic Creations
imageGallery.description: Discover the unfiltered potential of the open-weight engine. A showcase of unique art styles, experimental concepts, and diverse aesthetics favored by the developer community.

how_to.title: Unleash Creative Freedom with Dev
how_to.description: Use the model that powers the community's innovation.

steps.title: 1. Select Flux.2 Dev
steps.description: Choose 'Flux.2 Dev' to access the guidance-distilled engine. This version is known for being more 'raw' and artistic than the commercial Pro version.

media.alt: Selecting Flux.2 Dev on the interface.

steps.title: 2. Adjust Guidance
steps.description: Flux.2 Dev responds uniquely to guidance scales. Lower values allow for more creativity, while higher values force strict prompt adherence.

media.alt: User adjusting the guidance scale slider.

steps.title: 3. Generate & Experiment
steps.description: Generate high-fidelity images. This model is the exact same architecture used by the community to train LoRAs, so it's compatible with many style presets.

media.alt: A gallery of experimental art styles generated by Flux.2 Dev.

useCases.title: The Developer's Choice
useCases.description: Flux.2 Dev is the backbone of the AI art community, perfect for experimentation and custom workflows.

scenarios.description: AI trainers use Flux.2 Dev on z-image.app to test prompts and concepts before committing to expensive local training runs. Since it's the base model for most community LoRAs, results here predict training success accurately.

image.alt: Comparison of different art styles derived from the Flux.2 Dev base.

scenarios.description: Indie devs prefer Flux.2 Dev for its slightly more 'creative' and less commercially-sanitized outputs. It often produces unique, gritty, or abstract concepts that are perfect for brainstorming game environments.

image.alt: A gritty, atmospheric concept art piece for a sci-fi horror game.

scenarios.description: Prompt engineers use Flux.2 Dev to study how the 32B parameter architecture interprets syntax. Because it uses guidance distillation, it offers a transparent look into the model's logic without the 'safety filters' sometimes applied to Pro APIs.

image.alt: A complex visual breakdown of how a prompt translates to an image.

scenarios.description: Hobbyists use Flux.2 Dev to generate high-quality fan art and wallpapers. It offers near-Pro quality for significantly fewer credits, making it the best value for personal, non-commercial exploration.

image.alt: Detailed fan art of a popular anime character in a realistic style.

features.title: Why Use Flux.2 Dev?
features.description: It bridges the gap between closed-source quality and open-source flexibility.

items.title: Identical Pro Architecture
items.description: Flux.2 Dev shares the same massive 32B parameter transformer architecture as the Pro version, meaning you get the same 'brain' but with a different licensing and guidance structure.

items.title: Guidance Distilled
items.description: Unlike standard diffusion, this model uses guidance distillation, allowing for high-quality images with standard CFG scales. It is more responsive to subtle prompt changes.

items.title: Community Standard
items.description: This is the model the world uses. If you see a cool 'Flux LoRA' or style on civitai or huggingface, it was likely built on top of Flux.2 Dev.

items.title: Efficient Inference
items.description: While heavy, it is optimized for standard GPUs. On z-image.app, we accelerate it using FP8 quantization, giving you the full 32B experience without the lag.

items.title: Unfiltered Creativity
items.description: Flux.2 Dev often has fewer 'safety rails' regarding style and composition compared to commercial APIs, allowing for more artistic, abstract, and experimental outputs.

items.title: Excellent Layer Control
items.description: The model excels at separating foreground and background elements, making it a favorite for designers who plan to photoshop elements later.

items.question: What does 'Open Weight' mean?
items.answer: It means the underlying mathematical weights of the model are public. For you, this means Flux.2 Dev is the standard version used by the community, compatible with most external tools and tutorials.

items.question: Can I use Flux.2 Dev images commercially?
items.answer: Generally, the Flux.2 Dev license from Black Forest Labs is for non-commercial use. If you need to sell your images or use them in ads, we recommend using Flux.2 Pro or Flux.2 Flex on our platform.

items.question: Is the quality lower than Flux.2 Pro?
items.answer: The visual fidelity is nearly identical. The main differences are the maximum native resolution (Pro goes higher) and the licensing. Dev is an incredibly powerful model in its own right.

items.question: Why use Dev instead of Pro?
items.answer: Dev is often cheaper in terms of credits and offers a more 'raw' interpretation of prompts. It is also the best choice if you are testing prompts for a workflow that involves local LoRAs.

items.question: Does it support the text rendering Flux is famous for?
items.answer: Yes, Flux.2 Dev renders text exceptionally well, far surpassing older models like SDXL. It is great for memes, posters, and book covers.

items.question: What is the best guidance scale?
items.answer: For Flux.2 Dev, a guidance scale between 3.5 and 5.0 usually produces the best balance of prompt adherence and visual quality.

items.question: Is this model censored?
items.answer: Flux.2 Dev has fewer behavioral filters than some commercial APIs, but z-image.app applies its own safety layer to prevent illegal or harmful content generation.

items.question: Can I fine-tune this model?
items.answer: You can't fine-tune it directly on the website, but Flux.2 Dev is the specific version you would download to train your own LoRAs locally if you have the hardware.

cta.title: Start Experimenting with Flux.2 Dev
cta.description: Join the open-source revolution. Access the powerful 32B model that is defining the future of AI art.
